worklogs.comment:
sunchao commented on pull request #3276: ARROW-3665: [Rust] Implement StructArrayBuilder
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3276
 
 
   This implements `StructArrayBuilder` which can be used to build struct
   arrays. There are some trickness in terms of being able to store child
   builders of different types. A natural way is to box them into
   `ArrayBuilder` trait and store in a vector. But, this makes it
   impossible to cast them into specific type in `field_builder()`.
   
   To solve the above issue, this maintains two references to each input
   builder instance, one in `Box<Any>` type and another in
   `Box<ArrayBuilder>` type. The former is used for casting mentioned
   above, while the latter is used for calling general methods on an
   builder, such as `len()` and `finish()`.
   
   To enable this, this also changed `ArrayBuilder::finish` to return a
   `ArrayRef` instead of a specific array. The old `finish` method is
   implemented on each specific array builder, so one can obtain, say,
   `Int32Array` from a `Int32ArrayBuilder`.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

paddyhoran commented on pull request #3276: ARROW-3665: [Rust] Implement StructArrayBuilder
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3276#discussion_r244452157
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/src/builder.rs
 ##########
 @@ -234,6 +232,9 @@ pub trait ArrayBuilder {
     /// type. In this case, one can first cast this into a `Any`, and then use
     /// `downcast_mut` to get a reference on the specific builder.
     fn as_any_mut(&mut self) -> &mut Any;
+
+    /// Returns the boxed builder as a box of `Any`.
+    fn to_any(self: Box<Self>) -> Box<Any>;
 
 Review comment:
   I think it's convention for `to_..` methods to take self by reference

paddyhoran commented on issue #3276: ARROW-3665: [Rust] Implement StructArrayBuilder
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3276#issuecomment-450465481
 
 
   I appreciate what you are trying to do here, but playing devil's advocate, does this update create an easier way to build `StructArray`'s?  I'm not sure, having to downcast on every `push` is a little awkward and we seem to be introducing a fair bit of complexity to get this feature.
   
   Wouldn't it be easier to build child array's yourself via the existing builders, etc. and then pass a `Vec<(Field, Array)>` to a constructor of `StructArray` (of course, such a thing could still be added with this in place)?
   
   Right now looking at the tests, even though you pass the child builders into the `StructArrayBuilder` you end up managing them individually.  You just have to access them through the `StructArrayBuilder`.
   
   Is there any way (via macros or otherwise) that we can provide a `Schema` to the constructor of the `StructArrayBuilder` and have the signature of the `push` method generated (i.e. it would take as many arguments as children in the builder)?  I'm assuming the answer is no, as I'm sure you would have thought about it already :) 
   
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

sunchao commented on issue #3276: ARROW-3665: [Rust] Implement StructArrayBuilder
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3276#issuecomment-450471113
 
 
   Thanks @andygrove  and @paddyhoran .
   
   > It might be more consistent with other code to use Rc or Arc instead of Box ?
   
   It is a bit different here - The `Box` is (mostly) restricted to the internal of `StructArrayBuilder`. Also, we need mutable references for `Any` and `ArrayBuilder`.
   
   To @paddyhoran 's point, yes it doesn't help much in case of non-null struct arrays, but is more useful when dealing nulls (BTW: I haven't implemented `append` yet - will add later).
   
   I'm also thinking about adding a new constructor:
   
   ```rust
   pub fn from_schema(schema: Schema) -> Self {
      ...
   }
   ```
   
   which constructs the child builders from the given schema. This should make it easier to use I hope.
   
   > Is there any way (via macros or otherwise) that we can provide a Schema to the constructor of the StructArrayBuilder and have the signature of the push method generated (i.e. it would take as many arguments as children in the builder)?
   
   Unfortunately I don't know a way to do this. However, we may be able to implement something like `arrow_derive` which can convert a list of Rust structs into a corresponding Arrow array via procedure macros. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3276#issuecomment-450493444
 
 
   > but is more useful when dealing nulls
   
   Yes, that's a good point I wasn't really thinking of.  I think the new constructor is a good idea, interested see how this turns out.  Thanks @sunchao
